element_texts.text: Completed

Chicago Illinois
Oct 1st 1888
H. B. Stone Esp.

Genl. Manager C. C. & G. R.R.  City

Dear Sir:  
Following find report of Opts H. H. F.; and F. W. dated at Aurora. Ills. H. H. F. Sept 27 & 28th and F? T?. W. 26th and 28th of Sept. 1881:  also Sept 29th 1888. & 30th 1888.
Opt. H. H. F. report's that at 8:30 he started out found Frisly at the Corner of Fox St. and B-way talking to Reed.  they left there and went to Youngs Cigar Store!?  at 9:15 Opt went around town until 11.30 a.m. without seeing any of the men.  then Opt met Mortimer T? asmer and Dumphy at Fox St. Bridge and they all went out to Farrellls saloon.  had some beer. -- Dumphy told Opt that the Company had issued a notice that they were willing to take 300 of the old men back and pay them what they struck for.  but the Brotherhood wants all or none. and would stick to it to the letter:!?  That the Company would in a short time be in the hands of a receiver if they did not take the old men back.: that accident upon accident happened to the extei?nt of 3 or 4 per day.  that no company could stand that any length of time!?  A stranger stepped up to the party and asked, if those men (meaning Bowles et al, ) really did not what they were accused of. if not, that:
Completed

was it a sham etc.  Dumphy answered saying he did not know:  but if they did they would be expelled by the Brotherhood that the Brotherhood did not want any such men.  but they must get a fair trial:  and that before it was proved against them:  they could not do anything. and still more they would not believe anything

    The Stranger says there were very severe changes against the men. -- Mortimer answered saying:  That the Detectives would do anything:  Dumphy then made a sign and they all left the stranger.  Opt going also.  when away from him Dumphy said he did not like the looks of the stranger:  Then he and Tasmer left:  Mortimer and Opt. went towards the Northwestern Hotel:  on the way Mortimer remarked that:  the stranger might have been a detective:  but he did not get much out of the party:  Opt then left Mortimer and after Dinner he met Westling and Westling told Opt the same story about the Company taking the old men back:  They went to Burns. saloon had some beer.  Opt left Westling there at 3.45 and went away.  found Frisbie on the corner of Fox St Talking with Gunnilaw?. Opt watched them from 115 Fox St.
     Tasmer said that Dumphy took the Stranger (heretofor mentioned:) for a detective:  Opt was unable to learn who or what the man was:  but says some of the strikers think and say. that every stranger they see are Pinkerton men.  Opt says he knows of Drummers and Agents leaving Town because they were being shadowed by the striking Engineers and some o fthem being Straight out and out. accused of being detectives
     Tasmer said he thought all.  the detectives have left Aurora.  that they cost a great deal of money and that the Company had none to throw away on
Completed

them as they had done.  Tasmer went on to say that if the report was true that the Company were going to take 300 men back.  that they would do it inside of 3 weeks.

    The Postmaster then came in and the speaker turned the subject and talked about the parade in the evening at 4.30 p:m.  Opt left and went to hunt Frisby:  found him at Youngs.  left him there went up B-way and met Hoyt and Barlow.  went into saloon no 19 B-way left them there at 5 30 p.m.  after supper Opt says he heard the men again talk about the Companys being willing to take them back:  but they say "all or none"phrase underlined and they say that they will soon all be back and nothing further will be heard about the Dynamite case which is all a put up job:  from beginning to end:  at 6 30 p:m.  Opt went to Schmit Cigar Store No 8 River St. met Ham? and Ed Schmidt and went to Headquarters to form a parade. -- Went into a saloon on B-way, and had some beer. -- and again at. no 28 B-way Opt says that which he was marching he saw. Bauereisen on B-way. and Firsby on Fox St bridge after the parade, Ham Schmidt Barlow.  started for Farrells.  they met Mortimer, Speelman, and all together went into Farrells saloon.  had some beer.  Opt shortly after left them there claiming an appointment went around Town. but did not see any of his men and at 10 30 he discontinued:  and went home.
     Sept 28th. same Opt further reports". That:  at 8 30 a.m. as usual he started out -- the first man he saw was Bauereisen  he went into the meat market (Binders) and then into the Cigar Store where Opt left him:  at 10. a.m. Opt saw Frisby at Youngs cigar store.  Opt went in and tried to pick up some news:  but heard nothing during the forenoon.  Opt saw Frisby in the afternoon
Completed

and watched him from Tasmers. Store up to 4 15 when he left there and went to Youngs -- at 5 p:m. Mortimer met Opt on the Corner La Salle and Fox Sts:  went to Short's saloon had a drink:  from there they met Rees (Cabinet maker in G.? shops and they all went to Farrells -- Mortimer told Opt. that he heard from some one ("thought it was Dumphy)" that Bauereisen issued a Circular to the brotherhood to stand firm as the Company was on it's last legs. and in a short time would have to give in.:  they left Farrells. and went North of Broadway met Bauereisen at Main St. they then went in to 28 B-way.  played a game of Pool.  Opt left them there -- went to supper. at the restaurant listened to a conversation between two Strangers -- that they (the strangers) would  not be surprised at all if the Brotherhood did not come out all right from this struggle -- one of them said. "the Brotherhood have thousands of men, working and all of them pay so much into the cash:  and that should they win now. that after year or two they would be bold enough to ask for anything they had a mind to, and all there would be to do would be to give in to them: -- they said That this was a strike on principal and that the Other roads ought to help the "G?." or they the "G?" would have lots of trouble ahead. -- the other man listened and said nothing Opt could not learn who the men were.

     Opt then left and went to find his men, found Frisby still at Youngs. then went around the Streets met Mortimer again, on B-way.  then shortly after met Barlow and Hays.  they all went to No 10 B-way played Dominoes there:  Opt wanted to leave them but had no excuse to get away, so stayed till 8.45
Completed

p.w. then left there and went to Youngs Cigar Store found Frishy gone,  Opt Slanled to find him, and finally located him at Farrells Saloon, he did not enter - however, but started over Fox St Bridge went to No 5 River St - Opt went into Schinidls Cigar Store and watched from there until 9.15 when he came out and went over York St Bridge met some Girls and talked with them awhile, then he and one of the Girls slanted trade and went into the North Western Yanels behind some loaded cars. stayed there about 15 min- and then Frishy came out by himself and hurried over River St. Fox St. and Lasalle St's home! and then Opt diserntinned for the day!
Wednesday Sept 26th 1888! Opr. T.W.
reports that - Today while at Youngs Cigar Store Opt heard quite an argument. about Bauerisen he-ing indited by the Grand Jury. for Conspiracy to ? a building in the town at Eola There was a ? made. and he "Young" said that Bauerisen would not be indited by the, Grand Jury of this County! and that if he was indicted he would not be convicted by the next Term of Court. and. "as for friends" the Brother-hood would pay all of them, - he also said that Broderick was some Crazy Fool that had been roped in by Boules,
Frishy said that the Brotherhood had received a letter form the E.J.E. road where they said they wanted 18 more Engineers and Firemen
A striking Engineer by the name of J.E. Minott sold his place on South 4th St. for $1400.00! this man is one of the Knights of Salor. and a nominee for Representation - Opt was around among the follow
Completed

my men. during the day ? Viz Barry, Grelcourt Miais. Weldon. Byron DeGerald, Dumphy, Frisbee McGraw, McTyre, Raymond, Ray and Drover.
At ??? Opt. met ?artly and Barry and was with them awhile then went to Youngs and played dominoe with some of the Strikers! and overheard their conversation: then went to Farrells Seiberts and Gramps saloon. met some of the above men. and while at the Depot Opt met Barry DeGerald ?autly and Drover?. and all together went to Korgels Room and played cards Opt did not want to go. but his companions would listen to no excuse. Opt played 1/2 [half] hour. lost 50 cts in order to divert suspicion then left them? And walked up the RR track to So Aurora. and remained around Harris Lunch Counter until after 130am. the boys before mentioned were in Korgels room.still! when Opt went to bed:
Sept 28th 1888. same Opt further reports; ?] he again tried to keep track of Bauerisen: Opt saw him come down from his house. and go to the Brotherhood hall and while shadowing there Opt was compelled to leave his position several times, on acct of people coming along and treating Opt Korgel and ?antley had Opt go to Shorts with them, and Bauereisen during that time might have come out of the Hall. as Opt did not see him again. until 8 pm. in the evening- Alschuler the Strikers lawyer went to Geneva today; Opt thinks the main thing the strikers are working for is to have the Dynamite Cases put off. from time to time until the excitement dies out.
Opt did not learn anything more about the let-
Completed

ter. supposed to have been received by the strikers coming from the 2. railroad Co.
Opt was around to the differen resorts of the strikers today; but there seemed very few around, At Youngs there are usually 3 or 4 strikers at Dominoes and pool.- the onlu 3 that hang around ? are ?antly Barry and Horgel. At Farrells there are very few- Means Farrell and ?uiman are the principal ones. at Sutub. Rogers. Barry. Dumphy. and Pearson are frequent hangers on:
Opt says at night he watched around the Depot and RR. track until a late hour, and as scored out there were no strikers around! Opt says he thinks that tomorrow {sept 29} there will be an official count of the strikers all over the g? system!
Sept 29th 1888. same Opt further reports that today  he met Johnson a striking switchman: ????? Mears ? and Barry and Opt was asked to go with them: that they were going to take a ride in the Country:- they went to Youngs and met Santly[?] who went along: ?norr? having said he could not go as he had to haul some coal for Riddles. and they then went to Martins saloon. played pool had some beer went to Shorts: Mears going after the team: at Wrights livery?, Opt thinks the money they had to go and have a good time they got playing poker. they drove to Geneva and stopped at the Harris Hotel: where they saw Eddie Billings. from Geneva they went to Bavaria then back to Amora.? coming into Amora. they stopped at Seiberts and told him they had been to Geneva and Seibert asked if they had seen Bauereisen there:- they then went to Farrells. and Mears took
Completed

the team how.
Whiel at Farrells Saloon Opr and Johnson (who was drink) got into a little fight and after sparring a little they were stopped by Farrell, and it was all made up. And Opr and Johnson became Friendly again.
Later, and while in Youngs, a stranger came in and Called Young to one side. Opr says that he knows that they were talking about him (Opr) - Opr heard Young say I guess not. Opr never saw the stranger before: Opr could not see where he went to
Dean has returned to Aurora and say he will get a new Baldwin Engine as soon as the E.J.&E. road gets their Engines!
Joe Williams expresses himself as satisfied he is a striking switchman is marries, and says he will not work so long as the Q pays him: from what Opr learned from Williams and other Switchmen: he believes that Engineers are trying to persuade the Switchmen to go to work: and that as yet none of them have done so that he knows of.
Opr says he expects a letter today from Supt Rhodes today or tomorrow having the names of the Grand Jury on it.
Opr was around the depot and Rail Road tracks in the evening as usual until a late hour: but nothing occurred of importance.
Sept 30th came Opr further reports that: This morning after writing his report he went to Youngs Cigar Store and saw the following strikers there: Gretcourt Watton Johnson Frisby Mears Freeman. They were talking generally and about an accident that had happened at Bristol and which they claim was the fault of the scabs. Leo Young said it was a wonder how people would
Completed

ride behind such men. Gretcourt made the same remark Freeman said most people think the strike is over: Weldo said, it would be over if they (the strikers) did not keep it up. Opt went to Schieklers unclear Store: and learned from DeGerald that there is trouble among the striking switchmen. Opt says he believes the Engineer Brotherhood wants the switchmen to go to work, and that the switchmen claim she pay as before until the Brotherhood furnishes them with employment. 
Opt also learned that the reason so many of the Strikers helped Dearborn as nominee for Representation from that District was because Alschuler was on the same ticket and asked th strikers to help him. 
Chas. Dean, a striking Engineer told the Cooper that the R.R. thought they had the best of the Strike but to just wait until after November. and see, there are other points to be considered:
This Dean, Opt says, is a great blower and has always talked this way - he had to sell a nice little home he had at No 83 New York St. as he did not have the money to pay what he owed on it.  Cooper is a Grocery man there and told Dean he was sorry for him: that he (Dean) would be walking on his uppers soon, if he did not go to work soon. A Man by the name of Fisher who boarded at the North Western Hotel : and works at Fraziers Wagon Works said there are very few people in Aurora. that have any sympathy with the Strikers and that there were none in their shop, meaning Fraziers. 
Opt was also talking with Jacob Shea. of unclear who remarked the same as Mr Fisher did: At Heecks in the evening Barry Koegle and
Completed

and Santley were together - these 3 men with Snover when not working are always together and are of different political views. 
Opr remained around the Depot and Rail Road tracks as usual and remained up until a late hour but nothing of an unusual nature occurred during the time he was around and being satisfied that every thing was quiet and would remain so until morning he discontinued.
Yours Respcty
Pinkertons National Detective Agency
per W.A. Pinkerton Genl Supt.
West Div.
Completed

Chicago Oct 4th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Genl. Mgr. C.B.&Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Opr. H.H.F. reports as follows
Aurora, Ills. Oct 2nd 88
This morning I started out as the usual time and went to the Post Office and received a note from F.W. to discontinue the Grand Jury case. I walked around and found Frisby at the cor. of Main St. talking to Koegel and shortly after I met Baureiseu in his buggy. He turned up Fox St. where he stopped and I saw a lady and a boy enter the buggy and then they drove up Fox. St. I met Hoyd and Hokinson on Broadway and we went into the saloon at 19 Broadway and had some beer. While we were there Westling & Maloney came in and Hokinson asked Westling in Swedish how they were getting along, if they still thought they would get back when Maloney spoke up and said they could all speak English and asked them why they did not speak it or if they were speaking about him. Westling told him no that they were speaking about the strike
Completed

and Maloney told them to speak English so they could all understand it. Hokinson then told Maloney that he need not tell him what he should speak that he would so as he pleased. I saw there was going to be a fight so I quieted them and then had some beer. Westling told me that he had been promised a job in Chicago but the other Switchmen would not let him go, they wanted the Brotherhood to get them jobs as they went out to help them. Hokinson and Hoyd wanted me to leave as a lot of men, strangers to them, came in & as these were men in the crowd that I had seen in Westling company before and there was nothing to gain, I left and went with Hokinson to look at his shop on La Salle St. close to the Q Depot. I left there and met Dumphy on the street and went into #118 York St. and had beer and from there we went to the Democrats printing office. I spoke of the R.R. Company and he said they they would soon come to terms. he said "I am busy in this business but I keep an eye on the Compaby all the time". Some of the printers came in and Dumphey's attention was drawn to the work so I thought it best for me to leave. In the afternoon I met Frisby, Koegel and Quinlain on York St. bridge and I followed
Completed

them, they went into #5 River St. and I went into Schmidt's cigar store and played dominoes with Schmidt for cigars until 4.30 P.M. when I saw the men come out & I followed them & they went to Young's Cigar store where I left them. I met Baureiseu on Fox St. and he went to the post office and from there he went the cigar store at #110 Fox St. I went into Fasmer's Cigar Store at #113 where I met Mortimer, he was talking politics with Fasmer and while I was listening to them the Postmaster came in and said that he wanted all the boys to go to Joliet on the 16th and as some had to go to Geneva on the 4th he could not go. "Well I guess we will all go to Joliet." said Mortimer & Fasmer. I saw Baureiseu leave so I left them and followed him . He went to a grocery store on Broadway and then went home. At 6 P.M. while walking on Broadway I saw Frisby, Reed, & Koegel & they all went to Young's cigar store. I passed by there at 7 P.M. and did not see any of them so I went to look for them but failed to find them. At 8.45 P.M. I went to #8 River St. and then to No. 5 River St. where I had a glass of beer but they were at neither place. I walked around until 11 P.M. when I saw Frisby going home on La Salle St. 
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons Nat'l Det. Agcy
by W.A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. West Div.
R
Completed

Chicago Illinois
Oct, 5th 1888,
H.B. Stone Esq.
General Manager C.B.&Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Following find report of Opr. H.H. F. dated Oct 3d & 4th, 1888.
For Oct 3d Opr reports the following:
I started at the usual time this am and met Hawkinson on York St. we went in a salloon 118 Fox St. - while there 2 young men (Stangers) came in and I heard the Bartender say to them "Have you got your money yet) They said no9 that they had two months pay coming to them, the Bartender asked (Whats the matter with the Brotherhood) - one of the men said he thought there was nothing the matter with the Brotherhood only they were getting around a little slow. I suppose. then Koegel came in and sat down and read the newspaper. - Hawkinson and I left he went to the shops and I started to B-way and Corner Fox and Lasalle I saw Frisby he went to Youngs. I met Tasmer on Fox St. Bridge we went into Farrells. we were speaking about politics all the time. And I left there at 11 a.m. saw Frisby at the Corner of Fox and B-way. - I went with Tasmer to his store and kept and eye on Frisby from then to
Completed

2/ 10a.m. when he went home. at 2 p.m. I went to the P.O. and received a letter from Supt J.C. McGinn to make arrangements to leave Aurora and come to Head Quarters, I concluded it would be best to leave Aurora in such a manner that it would not look suspicious if I should come back. I started home wrote a letter addressed it to myself - I wrote that 2 relatives of mine had just arrived from the Old Country and I was to go and see them at South Bend Indiana at 4 p.m. I met Burns in his buggy and he asked me to take a drive I went to N. Aurora with him and returned at 6 p.m. at Supper I met Spellman who wanted me to go to the Theatre with him I excused myself went to P.O. got my letter the 1st man I met was Mortimer also Tasmer. I told them I was going to South Bend Indiana, to see my Cousins but would probably return again to Aurora to see a Young Lady I have supposed to have been keeping company with, and also see if she would go with me: we went to unclear had some drinks: Mortimer expressed himself as sorry that I was going, saying he had been so used to have my Company. I then went home, told the same story to all. Mortimer soon came in and after Supper pressed me to go to the Theatre with him it being my last night there and having no reasonable excuse for me not joining the party I went along with them but learned nothing not heretofore reported-
For Oct 4th unclear Opr further reports as follows:
At 9 a.m. I started out. Met Tasmer on B.way went to Shorts had some beer. told him I was going to South Bend Indiana to meet 2 Cousins just over from the Old Country and would stay with them for a while
Completed

I then went around town and told the same story to all of my acquaintances in town at 11 a.m. I went to Hoyts shop Barlows Shop Hawkins Shop. told them the same story - and at Train Time 5.30 p.m. Mortimer and Burns said good by to me at the Train and I left for Chicago arriving here at 7.10 p.m.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons National Set. Agcy
per Wm. A. Pinkerton. Genl. Supt
West Division
Completed

Chicago, Jan 7th 1889
H.B. Stone Esq.
Vice Pres. C.B.&Q. Ry
City
Dear Sir,
Opr "J.O'B" reports as follows.
Thursday, Jan 3rd 1889
Today in Aurora,
I left my room at the Triumph Hotel and went to the barroom and unclear the office and met Kyle and Dean, engineers on the Q and fireman Golden. I had drinks with them and left and came to Geneva with them. I told them I was breaking on the C and N. W. Ry. running from Chicago to Clinton on Train 29 and 18 and after my second trip got hurt the night of the storm, They, seeing I was in sympathy with them talked quite freely. Kyle is a prominent member of the Brotherhood and is standing by Baureiseu right along. He is running extra on the Illinois Central but is doing very little and said the master Mechanic of the Central knew nothing about rail roading and as soon as he gets some thing else to do he is going to leave the Central. He spoke of the prospects of a new trial for Baureiseu and he thought he was going to get it. He said that Judge
Completed

Wilson told Sheriff Kelly to give Baureiseu the best rooms in the Building and not to lock him up and to feed him well. This was all I could learn from him and arriving in Geneva I went to the court House & remained there until noon.
The defence obtained a continuance until Friday, Jany. 11th when the motion for a new trial will be argued.
After dinner I went in to see Muck the Barber and treated him and tried to learn something from him but he would not talk. I tried to get his opinion in regard to the report of Trainer making an affidavit as to hearing Stewart express himself and he said that Stewart had very little to saw in the shop. Seeing I could learn nothing from him I left and went to Danford's Drug Store and bought some medicine for my supposed sore foot. Danford was talking about the case and mentioned Carey as the man who was one of the parties who took out the affidavits he did not hear any thing about Trainer. He had just finished telling that Smiley informed him that the affidavits were made out when Hanchets came in and the conversation was dropped. Alschuler also happened in and they got to talking about the case but as the remarks were of little importance, I did not make a note of them. During the afternoon I met Howell, Brown, Harris, Murdock, Porter, Carlyle and Cary and during the conversation
Completed

I failed to learn anything new from them. I learned from Danford that the only Juror who was known to have expressed him self was Morris Stewart but no one knew at what time?.
I find that I cannot get any thing from Carey, he is not doing any talking and is not going to give up any thing and that only thing I can do until I get the list of those who made out the affidavits is to keep close to those likely to talk.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton Nat'l Det. Agcy.
by W.A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. West Div 
a.r.
Completed

E.F.C.
Chicago May 2nd/88
H.B. Stone
Genl. Manager of the C.B.&Q.
City
Dear Sir
Following you will please find report of my operative "E.F.C."
Today in Brookfield. Apr 12/88
Opr this morning at 6.30 AM went to the Yards which was to relieve the night men and remained around all day untill 7 PM where he was relieved by the night guards: nothing of importance happing.
Friday, Apr 13th/88
Today Opr. went on duty at 7 AM with the day guards and relieving the night men at the same time. He layedoff in the afternoon to sleep and proceeded to the cub where the shooting took 0place with |2| two City Marhals and two of my operatives and after placing the men at each end of the cut he remained there untill the 12.15 PM passenger train went East where he discontinued: nothing happening of importance during this time.
Completed

Saturday Apr 14th/88
Today at 6.50 Opr went to the CB&Q Yards relieving the night men at the same time. He stationed the guards around at their regular posts and visited them all all day untill 1 PM when he was relieved: nothing of importance happening all day.
Sunday Apr 15th/88
Opr went on duty today at 6.50 AM and relieved the night men at the same time. He remained on duty all day and nothing of importance happened and was relieved at 7 PM by the night guards.
Monday Apr 16th/88
Opr. today went on duty at the regular time and stayed on all day. He reports everything very quiet, all trains running on time and no trouble of any kind up at 8 PM that night when he was relieved.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton National Det. Agency
by Wm. A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. of Western Div
Completed

GWM
Chicago May 4/88
Mr. H.B. Stone
Genl. Manager of CB&Q 
City
Dear Sir
Following you will please find copy of my Opr "G.W.M" reports
Thursday Apr 12/88
Today in Brookfield
At 7 PM Opr. went on duty with the guard and specials in the east end of the yard and around the depot platform. Nothing of importance happened during his time of duty.
Friday Apr 13th/88
Today at 7 PM Opr. went on duty and remained untill 7 AM the next morning at 6 AM at which time he was relieved by the day guards. Nothing of importance happened during his time on watch. 
Sunday Apr 15th/88
Opr. remained on duty today from 7 PM untill 6 AM the next morning without anything occurring.
Your Respectfully
Pinkertons National Det. Agency
by Wm. A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. of West. Div.
Completed

T.S.
Chicago May 3rd/88
Mr. H.B. Stone
Genl. Manager of the CB&Q
City
Dear Sir
Following please find the reports of my operative "T.S."
Friday Apr 13th/88
Today in Brookfield
Opr. went on duty today at 7 PM and after placing the men at their regular posts he visited them several times during the night and nothing of importance happened.
Saturday Apr 14th/88
Today Opr. went on duty at 7 PM and after placing the men he visited them several times during the night and everything remained very quiet all night.
Sunday Apr 15th/88
At 7 PM today operative went on duty with the night guards and visited the guards untill 12.15 AM when he was ordered to take charge of Engine #27 of train #2 from Kansas City which was to pull the fast train that would arrive in Brookfield at 5.10 AM. The Eng.
Completed

arrived at 12.45 AM when Opr. boarded her and remained untill it went to the Round House and remained there untill it came out again at 4.30 AM and remained on the Engine untill she pulled out of the yard: the Engineer examined the engine all over before starting and said every thing was all right.
Monday Apr 16th/88
Today Opr. went on duty at 7 PM and after placing the guards at their several posts he visited them several time during the night and nothing of happened during his stay on duty.
Wednesday Apr 18/88
Opr. went on duty today at 7 PM and placed the men around the yard at their different posts and visited them untill 7 AM the next morning when he was relieved.
Thursday Apr 19th/88
Everything remained very quiet there today Opr went on duty from 7 PM to 7 AM and nothing of importance occured.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons National Det. Agency
by Wm. A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. of West Div.
Completed

J.H.F.
Chicago May 2nd/88
H.B. Stone
Genl. Manager CB&Q
City
Dear Sir
Following please find reports of my operative "J.H.F"
Wednesday, Apr 11th/88
Today in Burlington
Opr. from 6 AM to 9 AM visited to specials. He then went to the Court House where the Grand Jury was in session and after consulting with the companies counsel they decided to continue the case before Judge Fleming and after returning & getting dinner the visited the guards untill 6 PM when the night guards came on and he visited there untill 11 PM when he discontinued nothing of importance happing all day.
Thursday Apr 12/88
Today Opr. went on duty untill 12 PM where he went to dinner and returned at 12.30 PM to the guards where he heard an Engineer who just came from Galesburg had been assaulted and his revolver taken from him in a saloon on the corner
Completed

of Main and Angular St. and Supt. Stewart told Opr. to try and find out who the partied were. At 7.30 PM Engineer Costello was assulted on the corner of Jefferson and Main St. and Opr thinks the assilants name is Henry Coleman. At 6 PM Opr. sent out the guards and specials detail'd for night duty and remained out with them untill 11.30 PM when he discontinued.
Friday Apr 13th/88
Opr. went on duty today from 6.30 AM to 12 PM and visited the specials: after dinner from 12.30 to 2 PM remained around the depot. He then went out with the city police to hunt up Henry Coleman the striker who assulted Enginner Costello and Opr. also think he is the man that took a revolver from Engineer Petty. They found this man at 4.30 PM and arrested him, his trail being set for 8.30 AM saturday. Opr. then went to his quarters and sent out the guards detail'd for night duty and remained out with them untill 11 PM when he discontinued.
Saturday Apr 14/88
Today from 6 AM to 8.30 AM Opr. visited the special parties detail'd for duty and then went to the police court to the trail of Henry Coleman who was fined $32.00 for assult on Engineer Costello and then rearrested and held for
Completed

Trail for assult and robbery on Eng. Petty of the Galesburg Division. From 6 AM to 12 PM Opr. visited the guards on duty and after dinner he continued visiting them untill ^ PM when the specials went on for night duty and he remained out with them until 11 PM when he discontinued nothing of importance happening.

Opr to day from 6 AM to 12 PM visited the specials police detaild for day duty and continued visiting them untill 4.20 PM when Opr. received word that the strikers were going to make a break for them that night. Opr. went up and saw the mayor who ordered the Chief of Police to put his officers on duty at the station and unclear crossing and Opr placed the guards at the boarding house, Round House and & the Switches also curve at the end of the yard but the strikers didn't show up. without any effect. Opr. "F" one of the guards afterward found a 32 caliber revolver in going his rounds where the strikers run along. Opr remained out untill 1.30 AM when he discontinued.

Following please find report of Operative W.L.
March 5th 1888
At 8.30 AM Opr. was at Union Depot there was no excitement, everything very quiet in the yards. Opr went to CB&Q Round House but not seeing an Engineers there, went to the Gault house, here he found a few men who were getting ready to go to the Grand Pacific Hotel. When Opr was on his way to report he could see the CB&Q men were getting ready to start to their hall, on 14th Street. They were all talking about the C&N.W. saying the Brotherhood of that unclear will quit work if Mr. Arthur will only say the word. The opr went at 10 oclock to the Grand Pacific Hotel. Mr. Arthur's clerks were sending telegraph dispatches to all the Brotherhood. One dispatch to Mr. Shay and out to Mr. Wilkerson advising them to get the Brotherhood men ready to prepare for a general strike. Supt. Harris of CBN called on Mr. Arthur and
Completed

consulted with him. The men laughed at Mr. Harris ideas. There is some talk of calling all the brotherhood Engineers on western roads to strike. this ehy have not decided yet. The boys say they will know it all at the meeting Tuesday night at Battery D. The opr. left at 9:30 every thing was quiet at the hotel.
Yours Respectfully

Chicago March 30 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen Manager C.B.&Q. Ry
City
Dear Sir
Following please find report of Opr W.L. in Chicago.
March 28" 1888
At 8 A.M. Opr went to the Pacific Hotel and got into conversation with some Engineers they said they intended to fight the matter out but did not anticipate any trouble. A committee from the M.P.R.R. are at present waiting on Mr. Arthur in rooms 34 & 36. Opr left and went to the hall on 14th  & Jefferson Sts where the railroad men were holding a meeting. Opr could see none of them, then went over to C.B.&Q. Crossing at 16th and found everything quiet. At the railroad tracks at teh foot of Taylor St. a gang of hoodlums were shouting at the C.B.&Q Ry men. Opr reported the matter to officer at 16th St and he said he would look after it. At the viaduch all was quiet. Opr went to several saloons learned nothing new, then went to Pacific Hotel conversed with one D.J. Kennedy of Hannibal MO. He said the Brotherhood was delivered to win the strike and that other orads would soon join them, this man also said that a joint meeting of Engineers, Switchmen, and Firemen would
Completed

be held and action of some kind determined on. All was quiet up to 8.00 P.M.
March 28" 1888
Today in Chicago Opr C.P. met Cap Selacy & Gallick, Engineers of the brotherhood. He unclear said there was nothing new on unclear at present that they would wait for a few days to see what the switchmen would do when their places were filled by scabs. He said he expected trouble any day as the switchmen would not allow the scabs to work quickly this man claimed that all the police would do would be to disperse the crowd and that the police would not see any stone thrown or any cars uncoupled. That is they would not see it even if it was not done. Gillick said it was the intention of the switchman on the "Q" to go out as soon as they had any excuse so doing and that the breakmen were also ready to go on very short notice. They seem to feel more encouraged now then they did two weeks ago. They claim to have three hundred and fifty thousand dollars in the treasury and all the men paid their wages who went out on the "Q" strike. Delacy was to see Arthur today he says he is as confidence of winning today as the day the men went out
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton Nat Det Agency
by Wm A. Pinkerton
Gen. Supt. West. Div

Report of C. Peterson
Chicago April 21st/88
Today I met Supt. McGinn at the usual place at 8 AM. After meeting him I went to the vicinity of 18th & State Sts. I met Engineer Gillick & three firemen at unclear State. Gillick told me that they did not expect to make any thing out of the Interstate Commerce Law unclear, as they call it. They are trying to gain the sympathy of the public, which they say they have lost to a certain extent by guilting or calling out the Switchmen. That they will continue to pay the Engineers & Firemen that are out for six months, which according to their Rules, they are obliged to do. That is he said if they could stand it. But, did not believe that half of the Engineers would pay their assessments next time. They will he said keep up appearances the best they can. That as long as they have any money left or can get enough to live on they will not acknowledge to the public that they are unclear.
They will meet at Frieburg's Hall
Completed

tomorrow T. will have a very small meeting they say as most of the Engineers have lost interest in the meetings. Today that they had better be at work than attending meetings. That, the only show for them now is to pay the Engineers & Firemen that are out. That this they are obliged to do to prevent any break in their ranks. 
Respectfully
C. Peterson
Completed

CP
Report of C. Peterson
Chicago April 22nd/88
After meeting Supt. McGinn this morning at the usual place, I went to the meet my Railroad Friends in the vicinity of State 8. 18th Strs. I met Capt Dulacey Gillick & unclear. They tell me that there is nothing of importance on foot. That they are waiting for the meeting of The Company Officials to take place and are in hopes that Mr. Stone will not be reelected. That some of other man will be put in his place & will make some consessions to them. Meet them half way in what Delacey says. They are willing to do now unless that the company insisted on their going back & giving in to them. They will hold out as long as they have a dollar left in the Treasury & can get what they added each of the Engineers & Firemen for. That there is where the Grand Kick will be made, when the next assessment is made. There has been several donations made. one by Eastern Engineers & Firemen. But only one assessment was made & that was of five dollars each. Delacey said that they would not give in that they were
Completed

beaten. unclear the reason that it was life or death with them. That they will have it out as long as they possibly can & if the worst comes they will be have to take their medicin. 
Respectfully,
C. Peterson


Report of C. Peterson

Chicago. Apr. 3rd 1889
H.B. Stone ESq.
Vice Pres C.B. & Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir, 
Following please find report of Opr "P.L.G."
Saturday, Mar 30th 1889.
To-day in Chicago I was with unclear Howe, he feels disappointed at being kept so long - he having made arrangements before he going Pittsburgh to be home this evening. I took him around town and entertained him the best I could and left him pretty well satisfied, telling him I would call for him at 10 o'clock tomorrow. I also gave him $15.00 to buy some under clothes and showed him that his detention was unavoidable. 
Sunday Mar 31st89
To-day in Chicago about 10 AM I met Kirke? Howe at the Briggs
Completed

2.
house; found him a little dissatisfied for having to remain so long, I treated to cigars & showed him it could not be avoided & he would get off the middle of this week anyhow. I again met him about 12.30 PM and after dinner took him around town & bought cigars, after supper took him to the theatre and at 11 PM retired. 
Monday Apl 1st 1889
At 8.30 AM I left Chicago with Howe for Geneva and about 11.30 AM the last man for the jury was accepted, and court adjourned until 1 PM and on court opening Mr. Thatcher opened the case for the prosecution. Court adjourned at 4.30 PM until 10 AM to-morrow to give Douohue & David a chance to go to Chicago tonight, I remained around the courthouse during the afternoon and around the hotel during the evening, 10 PM retired.
Tuesday Apl 2nd 1889
To-day in Geneva, attended court and did some errands for C.M. Davis such as going to station to send telegram. and about 3 PM after hearing Bowles evidence as to a
Completed

3
conversation between himself and Broderick, one of the defendants at the county jail in Chicago. Mr. Daws told me to go to Chicago and see Ralph Lee who Bowles said called him to the door which they, Bowles and Broderick talked through at the county jail, Bowles testified that recently he was called to the door, Pleading from the boys department to the mens department at the request of Broderick by Ralph Lee, who told him, Bowles, that some one was at that door waiting to see him. Bowles, and that through the door Broderick threatened evidence xc. Mr. Daws request was for me to go to Chicago and see the jail barber, Mr. Elmer, and Ralph Lee and see if they heard the conversation alluded to by Bowles in his testimony, I knowing the difficulty of doing this, telegraphed as follows
D. Robertson
You or Mr. McGinn meet me at depot to-night. Important. at 4.50 as Kirke Howe had given his evidence, and received his mileage and fees $54.80 from the
Completed

4. 
clerk. I started with him for Chicago on arrival there I met Supt McGinn at depot, and  explained matters to him, we then went to county jail and saw Beu Price, the chief clerk and through his kindness we saw Ralph Lee and jail barber, Mr. Elmer, the latter I think to evade the violation of prison unclear, or committing Broderick of doing so, unclear everything, but on seeing Ralph Lee, be acknowledged that he called Bowles to that door, he heard Bowles say "is that you Tomi? How is your little gird.", the next he heard was Bowles saying "oh, four, you can't or ought not to talk to me that way - Lee says he can't tell what was said from the other side of the door, as he did not want to hear what was going on. I am satisfied that when B. Price told Supt. McG and myself that no such conversation could take place, he really believed it - but- when I was talking through that door I could very distinctly hear the noise on that other side. B.P. confidentially told me, he did not think such a conversation
Completed

5.
could take place as he knew Bowles and Boderick were not friends, as Broderick said if he ever got a chance he would kill Bowles that all the officials feel kindly towards Borderick and he B.P. would have to pay since he went to the jail. He had acted as a gentleman minded his own business xc. But if he B.P. was summoned he would have to give Lee's statment and if Lee deemed it, he would have to contradict it, as the statement was made before Supt McG myself and B.P. the tattler named ought not to be mentioned, except it is actually necessary. About 6.30 Supt McG left us and about 7.30 PM I left B.P and went to the Briggs House with Kirke Howe and settled up with him and he went away satisfied and promised if he got unclear by notice, in case of other trials, that he would come as long as he was  unclear the matter. I paid all Howe's 4 unclear from his home, Pittsburgh, until his return to same city, showing him many attentions, and as humor him that he would be available again. At 10 PM

6.
I left him, Howes, and went home.

Chicago Apr 27th 1888

Gen. Manager of C.B. and Q
Dear Sir,
Following please find report of my operatives.
Thursday Apr 12th 1888
Opr. "C.P." Report
In Chicago to-day. Opr talked with Caplin, Delacy, Kenny? and Gillick who said the strike is lost and that they were beaten all around, but are going to keep on allowing the men pay for awhile yet or they would make a kick the next time they were assest. Delacy said "he didn't know how the company knew every move they made before they started. He said the Switchmen on the "Q" road did all they could for them and if ever they need it can have the last dollar in the Treasury. He said Chief Arthur is no good and he would be fired as soon as they could conveniently do so. Opr. then discontinued.
Sunday Apr 15th/1888
Opr. "J.H.F." Report
In Burlington today Opr. visited the
Completed

Chicago Apr 19/88
Mr. H.B. Stone
Gen. Manager C.B. and Q City
Dear Sir,
Following please find report of Opr. F.W.
Friday March 23rd/88
In Aurora today, besides going around among the different saloons and places frequented by the strikers, I reported the following to Mr. G.W. Rhodes in the evening. I located Mr. Emerson Engineer at W 24 Broadway the same places where Charley Mitchell lives at. I seen the night Yard Master of the C.B. and Q - a Mr. H. DeGerald in front of the Brotherhood Hall he was talking to |2| two Engineers, this was at12 PM noon. I was introduced to Mr. C. Baincord? an ex engineer. He claims that Ed Johnson the fireman that went back to work was a nephew of his and that Johnson was influenced by the woman folks. He said old Tom Bowron the Engineer who went back to work is a dirty son of a (B) for the Brotherhood gave him money to keep his family and
Completed

also payed Bronson's taxes and the day before be went back the Brotherhood gave him $70.00. He said he would never go back as he had been through the big strike of 1877 at Pittsburg and he would not give in here. There seemed quite all excitement here over some engineer from Mendota going back to work. The engineer's seem to have some movement on foot to bind the citizens together. They go around amongst most all the bussiness men and they have a talk as if trying to persuade them to something and they give out a card tied with ribbon with which the person puts through his buttonhole and sticks the card inside something after the fashon of tkts at a Race Course. The engineers had a meeting to night at their Hall it seemed to be purty well attended. At 8.30 PM in company with opr. R.G. we reported to Mr. G.W. Rhodes and received further instructions and explained to Mr. Rhodes just how Opr. G and myself is placed here.
Saturday Apr 14th/88
Report of Opr. J.S.F.
In Chicago today at 1 PM I went to the Union Depot and received an introduction to Gen. Manager Stone
Completed

I then took the train for Denver for the purpose of protecting him from assault at Galesburg. I was joined by Opr S.W.V. who accompanied me to Denver. Nothing of importance occured on the trip. When we were going into Denver Opr. V went in and reported to Mr. Stone. Mr. Stone told him that he was going to Colorado Springs at 7 AM Sunday morning and he did not think it was necessary for us to remain untill he came back. He told us that we could return to Chicago anytime we got ready. We arrived in Denver at 12.30 AM Sunday morning and then went to the Hotel and put up for the night. 
Saturday Apr 14/88
Report of Opr. W.B.T.
In Plattsmouth today at 9.15 AM I went for my laundry returning at 10.45 AM guard M. also went for medicine. At 7 PM I detailed the night force for duty. At 11 PM the east end switchmen claim a swith was thrown causing the tender to run of the track. They claim it was the action of strikers, but I do not believe it as these switchmen are very green and in my opinion are liable to leave open many switches. One of these fired a short from a revolver last night and if not traced to them by
Completed

our men it would have been said that the strikers done it. Guard M. is again on duty he having got over his sickness. From what the Agent said to me yesterday I am of the opinion that Opr will be here only a few days longer. At 12 PM Opr returned.
Tuesday April 10th/88
Report of Opr. "M.B.F"
At 7 AM "Opr" arose and found the day force on duty. At 9.45 AM "Opr" went to Plattsmouth with his laundry and returned at 10.30 AM. At 12 PM Opr detailed officers unclear and "S" to make the dinner. At 6.30 P.M. the night force relieved day men. At 8 PM Opr visited the men and found them attending properly to their duty officer "S" was taken very sick on post and Sergt. "E" relieved him from duty. unclear in the yard untill 11 PM. At 12 PM the switching Engine commenced working at the east end near the Kansas City R.R. crossing and Opr "M.B.F." and Sergt. "E" followed the engine down and stood near the striker's Hall. Opr meet (2) two men in front of the Hall who said it was "torpedoes" that was out on the track that scared the new swtichmen. Opr "M.B.F" says he received Mr. Pinkerton's instructions of the 9th unclear as to keeping struck watch on the men
Completed

oweing to the reduction of the force. Opr "M.B.F" says it is expected that the C.B.and Q Knight of Labor will go out here in 36 hours. The striking Switchmen here seem to be sure of victory, one of them said yesterday that the striking Switchmen will be back before long and that when they do they will have Chicago sure. At 1 AM Opr. returned.
Wednesday Apr 11th/88
Report of Opr "M.B.F"
In Plattsmouth today at 7 AM Opr. arose and at 9.30 AM "R.B" wished to return to Philadelphia and Opr. wrote Mr. P. for another man. At 2/20 PM the day force was discontinued by order of Supt. Duggan. I returned to Chicago by train No. 2 - 5 PM making this reduction "J.S" H.N. V.R.B and G.F. I wired R.A  Pinkerton of reduction giving the names and amounts to be deducted from their salaries. Opr. also wired Capt. Foley. At 7 PM the night force went on duty and remained untill 7 AM of the 12th.
Thursday Apr 12/88
Report of Opr M.B.F.
In Plattsmouth today Opr. arose and found the night force on duty. At 8 AM Opr. made a tour of the Yard and found everything O.K. Opr remained
Completed

around the depot during the day and at 7 PM detailed the men for night duty and visited them several times during the night and found them attending properly to their duties, nothing unusual happened during the day or night. Opr. "M.B.F." says he is in receipt of Asst. Supt. McGinn's letters of the 10th and 11 inst. relative to expense money drawn by "Mr. S" and self. In reply will say that Opr made out expense bills concerning the matter and forwarded them to Capt. Foley his balance due the Agency including the money given him by Mr. Shelby is $34.00 Mr "S" expense bill is $4.05 he gave Opr. "M.B.F" 95 cent which he got credit for in Opr. M.B.F statement for week ending Apr 7/88. Opr also has letter of the 11 inst. and in reply says that the guards here understand they must do good duty. Opr. enclosed letter received here today for J.J. Mathews he not being here. Everything is running smoothly. Opr retired at 3 AM of the 13th.
Wednesday Apr 11/88
Report of Opr. M.B.F.
In Plattsmouth today at 9.30 AM Opr forward report of complying with Supt. Duggan order to discontinued the days guard. He also forwards unclear given out by the strikers which reads as
Completed

follows "Boycott Mrs. Brown Pottery" - she patronizes a Scab road the "C.B. and Q"
Friday Apr. 13th/88
Report of Opr. "M.B.F."
In Plattsmouth To-day at 11 AM Opr. arose and done duty around the depot. At 7 PM the night force went on duty and remained till 7 AM of the 14th. Opr visited the men several times during the night and found them attending properly to their duty. M. Mulhern was taken sick last night and tonight he is unable to perform his duty, had a doctor and expects to be all right tomorrow. I forwarded pay roll and expense bills to Capt. Foley on train No. 3- 5.55 PM/ Nothing unusual occured during the day. At 2 AM 14, I retired. I received Capt. Foleys message to close pay roll each Friday.
Saturday Apr 14/88
Report of Opr. "M.B.F."
In Plattsmouth today at 9.15 AM went to Plattsmough as previously stated also send by mail statement of "J.S" for cash received. 
Sunday Apr 15th/88
Report of Opr. "M.B.F"
In Plattsmouth today at 7 AM Opr arose and done duty around the depot during the day. At 7 PM Opr detailed the men on night duty and visited them several
Completed

times during the night and found them attending properly to their duty. At 1 AM Opr. retired. Opr, has Asst. Supt. J.C. McGivens letter of the 14th in regard to $50.00 drawn by "M" Opr sends his expense bill and statement by today's mail and will give credit for balance due Agency. 
Saturday Apr 14/88
Report of Opr "J.B.N"
In Atchison to-day nothing unusual occured. The trains were on time and we had no trouble of any kind with the strikers. Our men performed their duty well. Everything is very quiet. Opr. received a telegram today from the Supt. at Lincoln Neb. asking him to send the one man at Table Rock to Falls City on first train. Opr. informed Mr. McSonniff that he did not have charge of that man at Table Rock but Sergt. P. Savage did at Falls City. Opr. is in receipt of favor of the 12th $10.00 also blanks. Opr will forward expense report at an early date.
Saturday Apr 14th 1888
Report of Opr. "T.N.V."
In Galesburg to day at 9 AM at Brown's Hotel where Opr. received a message instructing Opr. to meet Opr. "F" on train leaving Chicago at 1 PM prepared to meet and leave on that train. Upon
Completed

meeting Opr. "F" at Galesburg on train No. 1 at 6 PM Opr. was given a letter of instruction in regard to looking after Gen. Manager Stone private car which was attached to this train. So Opr left on this train in company with Opr. "F" after obtaining around trip ticket from Mr. Maberly. Oprs occupied the Sleeper immeadeatly in front of Gen. Manager's Stone car and got out and looked about at each stop, but there was no attempt to do any harm during the trip.
Saturday Apr 14/88
Report of Opr. Capt. "P.F"
In Plattsmouth today your message received I noted. Will attend to it. Am sorry to hear sad fate of Thorwald Lund. Hope theother man is not fatally injured. Everything passed of quietly here today. The (2) two Switchmen who the Strikers bought of are now going around with the strikers one of them named Chas. Ellis is drunk today and may prove troublesome. 
Saturday Apr 14th 1888
Report of Opr "G.E.W"
In Aurora to-day I had to talk with John Laws? who was a special policeman at the time of the fire and he was in the department where the engineers sleep in the unclear Shop. Opr. unclear
Completed

of the commisary Dept. run through the door that was open and seen the fire through the partition. I did not see any suspicious parties around the outside at all. So a man was stationed at this door and there was no chance for any one to get in this door as Opr unclear was there. I then fell in with a man named Bailey this man is among the strikers and a very bitter fellow, he is also the slugger for the Switchman and is a great talker. Opr. had a talk with this man Bailey in a Livery Stable where Opr. is acting as a Horse Trader. Opr. got Bailey talking about the fire where he stated he was one of the first to get to the fire and saw the scabs comming out of the burning building. Hickey says the fire was not set by any one as it was too early in the evening where the fire broke out and thee was to many police around so that anyone setting the fire would stand a poor show of getting away. Hickey said well they did give the scabs hell while they were getting out of the building. Hickey said unclear their as bad as I hate them. Opr stopped up late to night but nothing occured. It is very hard for Opr, to get close to these
Completed

people as they are very watchfull. Opr. left this man Hickey at 11 PM and retired.
Aurora Sunday Apr 15/88
Report of Opr. "G.E.W."
In Aurora to-day soon after comming out Opr met the man Hickey also a striking fireman named McInhill and Opr. was with them the most of the day in front of Hitchcock Livery Stable where the main crowd stood watching the trains passing. Opr. in conversation with McInhill to-day the latter said he was at the fire and that he thought it good enough for the "Scabs" to be roasted. Opr. thinks McInhill knows nothing about the origin of the fire an neither does Hickey. Opr. in conversation with an engineer and a Saloon Keeper named Jacob Short to-day learns that a partition was put up to divide the sleeping room from the from Shop and that this partition was dry and the seams between the boards wide enough for a person to see through and the engineer thought no one would set the fire where he would be apt to be caught. Opr had a conversation tonight with a man named Frazer one of the citizens called on to investigate the origin of the fire who said he was satisfied that the fire was set by some one. Mr. unclear of the same place is of the same opinion as is Mr. Marhall another citizen. The last unclear two are for the railroad company and express
Completed

themselves very plain and openly on the subject. Tonight Opr called on Mr. Rhodes Supt of M.P of the road and made a verbal report of the fire. Mr. Rhodes thinks there is no changes to make an incendiary case out of this. Opr. will attend a meeting tomorrow night of which he will give a report to Mr. Rhodes and then report to Chicago. 
Sunday Apr 15th 1888
Report of Opr. "M.B.T"
In Plattsmouth to-day at 7 AM Opr arose and did duty around the depot. At 7 PM Opr detailed men on night duty and visited there several times during the night and found them attending properly to their duty. At 1 AM Opr retired for the night. Opr has Supt McGivens letter of the 14th on hand at so $50.00 drawn by Mr. Mulhern. Opr. sends expense bill and statement by today's mail and will give him credit for balance due Agency.
Sunday Apr 15th 1888
Report of Opr. Sergt "J.B.W."
In Atchison today everything passed of very quiet. 
Sunday Apr 14th 1888
Report of Capt. P.F. or "M.F.D"
In Plattsmouth today Opr says it has been a very quiet day and that the K. Of L. are to hold a meeting there this afternoon to induce the Shopmen to go out but the opinion here is that they will not go out.
Completed

Opr. says that if any revolvers are sent for this week he would like two or three sent to him. He hopes everything is quiet at Omaha and that Lunds corpse is sent to Chicago allright. Opr says he met the (3) three men at the train last evening and kept Opr "W.H" here. Last evening at 8 PM an old man an Engineer who runs No 37 during the day was assulted by some strikers in front of the Post Office when an special policeman who was just sworn in tried to protect him and was knocked insensible by being struck with a "billy" in the side of the head. At 12 PM the same special policeman was coming down the main St. when a man jumped out and tried to stab him with a knife where he began to shoot and nearly shot an Alderman who is also an ex Engineer and was in the way. The excitement was kept up untill 1 PM. The strikers kept away from the railroad track during the rows last night and did not trouble the men at work. Op is informed that the strikers are trying to have a striking engineer appointed City Marshall. Opr does not think they will succed at although they have one of their men (Connors) appointed to the Council. Opr is informed that the new Mayor will visit certain R.R. Officials in Omaha today. Opr thinks Trafton was little scared when he left here.

Sunday Apr 15th 1888
Report of Opr J.D.R.??
In Holdrege today Opr tried to get the Engineer that was assulted to swear out a warrant as the party is know but he refused to do so. I can not do anything more in the matter. Opr. says that the strikers there are not so friendly now as they were three weeks ago but have not given any trouble at the depot yet. 
Sunday Apr 15th 1888
Report of Opr T.N.V.
In Denver today Opr. says that they left Omaha this morning & arrived in Denver at 12.30 midnight. Before reaching Denver Opr. presented a card of introduction asking for instructions from Mr. Howe and was informed that he would leave for Colorado Springs at 7.30 AM and did not think it necessary for Opr "F" and Opr. T.N.V. to remain and instructed us to report to Chicago. After seeing that everything was all right for the night Opr. went to bed.
Monday Apr. 16th 1888
"T.N.V." Report
In Denver this morning Opr "F" and Opr. "T.N.V." left for Chicago. They will be on the road all day Monday and Tuesday and will arrive in Chicago at 8 AM. Wednesday April 18/88 and reported at Agency.
Monday Apr 16th 1888
Opr. "F.W" Report
Completed

In Aurora To day In going around among the strikers Opr. learn that the Switchmen were very anxious to do some harm to the R.R. Co. but the Engineers oppose it. Opr. F.W. says that in conversation with the Hackman Watkins who is the father is an Engineer said there would be trouble as he did not think the Switchmen would stand by and see their places being filled without some demonstration. Opr says that Bob Hickey who is the fighter of the strikers said "there would be trouble before night." Opr says he heard a newsboy say the same thing as the boy heard it was to occur at 3 PM. Opr immediately posted Opr. W.J.M. and Mr. Wilson of this information. During the afternoon Opr. traveled among the strikers and learned that they have a good many rubber sling shots for throwing stones and that Mr. Wilson knows the men. Opr. says that while standing in front of Wilsons Cigar Store with a crowd of strikers there was a report of a scab shot a striker at the Cor. of New York and Broadway but it proved to be an accidental shot from the new Engineer pistol while scuffeling with some strikers who attacked him. There the scab was arrested causing great confusion going down the St. the crowd of strikers saying "lynch him" "lynch him" finally the police come & took prisoners to the City Prison.
Completed

The storekeeper where this occured says that the strikers come up and kicked the new man who acted like a gentleman. Opr furnished Mr. Wilson a description of two other men who assulted this man. Among the crowd that yelled around the Jail he was in, was Joe Wilson, Geo. Buthold, Reddy Snow, Frank Walker, Chas. Howard, Stanley Smitty, Kramer, Murphy Mears, and many others and Bob Hickey who was there said "he had a punch at the scab". Opr says at this point there was a meeting called can this took the strike off the streets. The Police kept good guard around the city as Opr walked around the streets and R.R. tracks untill 2 AM when Opr made this report to Mr. Wilson.

Tuesday Apr 17th 1888
Opr "M.R." Report
Completed

In Buda today Opr says the day opened with a large crowd of strikers sympathizers and idlers around. They were generally discussing the strike and the R.R. wreck near Creston Ia. Some blamed the engineer and other it was the Conductors fauly for running on anothers train time. This discussion was kept up untill their attention was called to the first train comming in which brought Mr. Ladd of Keewanee also Mr. Price and Opr proceeded to bring the witnesses together in Grassley's office but when the time come for them to testify they all acted as though they were afraid. Opr and Mr. Grassley tried to refresh their memory but without any effect. Mr. Ladd held that this was insufficent to hold the car uncouplers on as only such evidence as to the parties being seen in the act would be of any use before a jury besides they must be other than R.R. hands to testify. Mr. Ladd tried to get Geo. Jink to squal and left for that purpose. Opr says that as soon as the news of the attys being in town the crowd was excited and more so when the witnesses - the switchman, Flagman, and watchman came out of the office for news of what had transpired and speculated as to the result. Opr. says that all the town and country people around there seems to be relatives. At 6 PM Opr
Completed

meet Mr. Ladd who said he was unable to get Geo. Jink? to squeal and Opr. thinks he never will. He lingered about untill 9 PM. Last night the strikers broke a hole in a car that was side tracked and loaded with corn, besides tearing down a lamp post near the track. Opr says Patrick Ford and others were around Sunday night threatening to whip anyone charging them with the above otherwise everything was quiet during the night.

Monday Apr 16th 1888
Opr. "H.D." Report
In Creston to-day at Opr arrived at 7 AM and immediately had breakfast after which he took a walk over the Company's property
Completed

and found everything in good order Opr went to Supt Duggans office and he informed Opr that he could do away with the day watch and let the men that are doing day duty go on at night. Opr says everything is very quiet here in town and that very few of the strikers are seen on the street. Monday Apr 16th 88
Opr G.D.C. Report
In Galesburg this morning at 8.30 AM Opr. left the Hotel accompanied by John "H" and "S" and proceeded to the white elephant saloon where they met Engineer McDowell and he told them about the wreck near Creston Ia. He said "the scab engineer and Fireman got killed." He said the watched the trains report in the paper but did not seen anything of it and thing the "Q" is keeping the matter quiet. Opr says a letter come to the Headquarters giving all particulars. Roberts and Harris made their appearance and Roberts told McDowell that old Marin had arrived, also several visitors who had arrived
Completed

and had been all over the road. They speak at the Hall tonight and tomorrow night all members are invited to bring their wives and daughters as they are going to have a meeting afterward the concert and dance. Opr treated to the drinks. Roberts said within the last week 6 scabs switchman had their fingers taken of he then laughed and said everything was coming their way. Opr. then proceed to Mom's saloon where he met J. Creen who bragged of doing up a scab foreman saturday near the dept. They played cards at this place untill 11.30 PM when Opr. left accompanied by Mr. Hinkson and proceeded to the Hotel where they met Waidcote who has not been able to leave the house for several days on account of sickness. He said the men are going to work at the same rates other roads are paying. Hinkson told him was misstaken. He said they know nothing about it at the Hall. At. 2.30 PM Opr left the Hotel with Harris, Roberts, and Hinkson and proceeded to the White Elephant Saloon where they met Engineer Johnson and fireman Reilly. Johnson told the switchman that they would go to work soon and Roberts said "he wish the strike would last all summer and that the new" the
Completed

Switch boys were willing to take a good lay off. Hailienine? made his appearance he is Secy. of the Switchman Union and said everything is comming their way now. He said he heard Old Martin say today that the men would go back soon. Opr. treated the drinks and left the saloon with Hinkson and went to all the saloons on Prairie St. in the vicinity of the Hall and met a good man strikers who do not think the strike will last very long as the company will come to their terms. At 5 PM Opr. went to the Clifton Hotel, Stanburg and Waidrope met Tom Deapenbold the same as usual who gave account of what happened at the round house during the day. At 7.30 PM Opr left the Hotel in company with Roberts and Harris and proceeded to a saloon near Brown's Hotel where Opr. treated when they separated, the two latter going to the Hall and Opr returning to the Hotel where he met Hinkson and played cards untill 9.30 PM. At which time Roberts and Harris returned and Roberts talked of the meeting saying "Old Martin, two Chicago engineers, and a B. and M.R. pay" - made speeches and expected the company would meet them halfway on their terms, and the strikers wives and daughters all expected at the concert and dance after the meeting.

At 11 PM Opr. retired.
Monday Apr 16th 1888
Opr "G.E.W" Report
In Aurora to-day by order of Mr. Rhodes. Opr. remained over untill monday night untill the Counsel met but at that time there was not a quorum and they could not act on the fire investigation untill wednesday night. And operative in conversation with some members of the concil learned that they were inclined to make it accidental instead of incendiary. Opr then found the man Hickey and was with him untill mid-night and was satisfied he knows nothing of the origin of the fire. Opr also talked with several engineers but they are very carefull about talking to strangers and did not find out anything of importance. Opr says the Council will make their report on the paint shop fire wednesday of thursday. Opr then retired at 1 AM. 
Tuesday April 17th 1888
Opr "W.J.M." Report
To-day in Chicago Opr after taking Perry examined by Dr. Ballard of 119 Madison St he took him in company with councilman Corbit of Aurora to a restaurant and had supper after which they proceeded to the Briggs House and retired for the night. Opr arose at 9 AM. Took breakfast and reported at the Agency to Supt. McGiven and at 12 PM took the fast mail train for Aurora where

25
he reported to Supt C.G.W. who informed him that he had wired to Chicago for (12) twelve good men to do patrol duty under the supervision of the City Marshall and to be known as the employees of the C.B. and Q R.R. At 6 PM on the arrival of the freight train which stopped the freight yard. Opr. met Mr. James Patton with (11) eleven men and instructed them as to their duties and sent them to the City Hall to report to the City Marshall who placed them patroling the streets this made (36) thirty-six men appointed including the (12) twelve that came from the Agency and the city officers do not know these (12) are Pinkerton men. At 8 PM Opr had an interview with officer "W" and told him what he was to find out as to the assullt of Perry and all witnesses and of (2) drummers who stopped at the unclear Hotel also to find out who of the strikers carried sling shots. Opr. says everything is quiet up to 10.30 PM and that he will leave for Mendotta tomorrow. Mr. Wilson Opr says sent the letter to the company Counsel at Galesburg for investigation where it will be returned to Opr. who will return it to Agency.

Monday Apr 16th 1888
Opr A.C.J. Report
In Chicago to day Opr went to Gen. Managers Stones Office to report to Attorney Collier and he not finding him in reported to Supt. McGinn under whos orders he proceeded to the vicinity of the shooting and if possible obtain further information. Opr then proceeded to the Turner Hall where a large crown was assembled and appeared to be railroad men there seemed to be nothing but excited conversation going on. he then proceeded down Halsted St. visiting several saloons and afterward went to the Wabash RR crossing at 418st St where he met a man who keeps a saloon and Barber Shop at #531 Root St; he lives quite close to the R.R. and he said he he heard the engines whistleing but did not know untill afterwards where he was told that a Wabash Engineer had been shot. Opr then went into Gibbons Saloon where he

met two men talking about the shooting and looked like railroad employees one of them said "when the shot was fired all the boyes around the Water Tank picked up and fired lumps of coal at the "Q" engine but it was going to fast to be unclear: these men work on the Wabash RR and one of their names is Lowder. Opr. after unclear to the Hall and getting in further information discontinued at 7 PM.
Tuesday Apr 17th 1888
Opr "A.C.J." Report
In Chicago to-day Opr at 9.15 AM under instruction from Supt McGinn he went to the vicinity where the shooting of Michael C. Walsh took place and unclear around at every house to find some one that knew something about it but was unsuccessfull. Everybody seems to express sympathy with the striking railroad employees of the C.B. and Q. Opr then tried to find out the history of the dead engineer who is Irish and lived with his brotherinlaw J.W. Morgan at 556 42nd St where he was buried from he has worked for the Wabash R.R. for about 9 years and had the reputation of a sober and industrious man. He has an aged mother living at No 4081 Atlantic St. He was 28 years old and a member of the Forresters and of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers Div 302

Walsh's brother was shot and killed at 43rd St and the tracks (5) five years ago it was supposed by tramps. Morgan the Brotherinlaw works for the Wabash as fireman and he says he was in the immediate vicinity when the shooting occurred and says the was only a few persons around as it was raining and very disagreeable. He said there was no stone throwing but the engines along the track sounded their whistles (meaning a scab engine was around.) Opr then called at the home of Boylan? the boy who was shot at the 47th St. crossing but the doctor left word for him not to be disturbed so Opr could not see him and at 7 PM discontinued.

Opr. "C.P." Report
In Chicago today Opr. meet Sanderson, Delucey Sheehan and Gillick and Gelleck told Opr. they were discouraged, that every move they made so far was a failure and the company seemed to know their plans as quick as they did them themselves and they were depending primarily on the switchmen and they were going back on them. Opr says a machinist who works for the C.B. and Q and boards with him says the machinists in the shops would just as soon see the strikers downed as not. His name is unclear unclear He also said "they seemed to think they only had to demand any sort of wages and receive it." Opr says the strikers are only hoping that the company will meet them half way and compromise in some way Opr could not learn any more and discontinued.

Chicago Aug 1st 1888 H. B. Stone Esq Genl. Mgr. C. B. & Q. RR City Dear Sir: Following you will please find report of Officer J. M. Thursday July 26th 88 Today in Mendota at 6:30 P.M. officer went on duty and found all safe remained so during his time on duty. We he left at 6:30 A.M. all was in good shape. Friday July 27th/88 Today in Mendota at 6:30 P.M. officer went on duty and found every think alright and remained so until he left at 6:30 A.M. Mr. Nickson called officers attention to-day to one of the old engineers, who was running a freight & is a Galesbury man this makes his fourth day. Pomeroy the night yard master here quit and has gone to Aurora to take an engine and there is an old engineer here who behaved himself during the strike who is about making an application for work. Yours Respectfully Pinkertons Natl. Det. Agency By W. A. Pinkerton Genl. Sept. W. Div   initials ?
Completed

They say that a corporation who refused to submit the question "whether there was anything to arbitrate" or not through fear of having to settle with us, is to contemptable to subject any brother to the humiliation of entering into their services So they pledge their support indefinitely. Now since our Brothers have decided never to go to work for the company without a settlement, it is our duty to retain the good name which we have already won and strictly condem anyone that commits any overt acts.
From the facts which we have in our possession we know the road can not be run successfully without the old men; the men they have are a class who always, before a great while, proved themselves to be extremely expensive to their employers and we can rest assured that they will not be an exception to their former lives while in the places that we tried to make the highest standard of excellence,
An extra session of the convention will probably be called to take action in regard to our affairs.
Reports from every point show that the Bro. are happy and contented. Fraternally, Howe & Murphy.
Completed

Chicago June 11th 88
H.B. Stone Esq
Gen Manager C.B. & L.R.R.
City
Dear Sir
Following you will please find reports of my operations
Saturday June 9 - 88
Today Hoge received his weekly draft from Cleveland ? and said that the men had all been paid for the third time excepting ? our point
Hoge remained in the room the greater portion of the day, there were a few men who called from other roads and three or four of the regular frequenters of the room. They talked the strike over. 
Hoge called the attention of some of the men to the letters he received from some of the strikers and others and said that in answering these letters if he did not say something encouraging in town, there would be no notice taken of them as the men do not want to hear the real facts of the case. Hoge remained to ? of
Completed

the Chicago strikers, they had been very foolish to continue the strike and that it would be a year before half of those men would be able to obtain work and that if he was to come right out and declare the strike off they would accuse him of selling them out, as he had fought against he demand two years ago and again a year ago and now he would just stop here as long as they wanted him to. that he would ask again go back to railroading as he had had offers from there different insurance companies.
Hoge rehearsed the strike from its commencement and related the result of the different meetings with the rail-road officials. No news of any importance today Hanrahan was not in today. At 5pm the room was closed and all hands left. Hoge was out the balance of the evening. 
Saturday June 10th/88
Hoge was not in the room to sleek last night and did not come in till 11:30a.m., he remained just long enough to read over the mail. Charley Touelisonbest guess was with him, they then went to same engineer's house for dinner where Hoge's little girl went to visit yesterday. No person else was in the room during the day or evening
Completed

Friday June 9 - 88
Today Opr C.P. reported to Supt Murray and ? week out to meet the engineers and switchmen. At 1713 Stae St. he met Captaincies Delacy who said that he had not been down town and would not call on Hoge today because there was nothing he could do before Saturday or Sunday and even these he did not expect anything that they had been beaten in every more they had made. Several others who Opr talked with said that there was nothing of importance going on. The switchmen agree with the firemen and engineers in say that at their next convention they will remove all their present officials and try new ones. That new ones cannot do any worse than the old ones have been doing.
Sunday June 10th - 88
At 8a.m. today Opr reported to Supt Murray and ? week out amongst the railroad men. At 1713 State St. he met Gillian who said he was not going to the meeting as he was not going to pay another assessment. Sanderson ? Delacey went to the meeting of Division No 10 - No 142-4 Twenty Second St. Opr then went to the Captain's house No 2222 Dearborn St. ? as he had company Opr could not see him alone. Opr has to
Completed

be very careful with him as he is an intelligent man and may get suspicious Opr will meet Delacey and Tillick tomorrow and find out from them the result of the meeting. Opr could not find Sanderson either today or yesterday but will try again tomorrow.
Saturday June 9 /88
Today in Chicago at the National Hotel Opr. D.D. remained about the reading room most of the day. At about noon Fawlen, Murphy and a man they call Winkle left the Hotel with their valises and went in the direction of the Union Depot. Opr ? went to his room and there learned that these men had gone to Aurora to meet a committee of switchmen. Opr could not learn the object of the meeting. Fallen returned last evening bringing a new man with him and ofter supper they went to the Grand Pacific Hotel and afterwards stood out in front of the Hotel unit after 11 o'clock. then went up to their room which did not have anything of importance to say This new man is from Denver his Christian name is ?. Opr has not learned his last name yet 
Sunday June 10 - 88
Today Opr D.D. reports that there was very little going on at the National Hotel as they were out nearly all day
Completed

Some of the brotherhood men from Pittsburg and other points are expected here tomorrow and will hold same kind of a conference. The man from Denver who came with Fowler is a very vicious and bitter talker. In the course of conversation he said "we must make some kind of a move that will teach the company a lesson for all time to come and let them know that we mean something". Fowler said "But we must not do anything to hurt us before the public for if we do we will get the worst of it, and we must not do anything to hurt the brotherhood.
Many of the men seem to want to be destructive but are held in check by Hoge.
Murphy will be back again Monday from Aurora.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons Nat Det Agcy
by Wm A Pinkerton
Gen Supt West Div
