Chicago. July 17/88. H. B. Stone  Esq. Genl. Mgr. CB&Q Ry Chicago. Ill Dear Sir, Following you will please find report of the D.D. Friday July 13/88. Today in Chicago, at the National Hotel the opr says there has been a great many new men here today who came to attend the trial. Bourisen & Hope had a long talk this morning, also in the afternoon. Hope got very angry at some thing that was said, & said "I will teach that Son o f a B. to keep his mouth shut"; the opr. says he dont know who he had reference to, unless it was Kelly. Bourisen is very much affraid that Bowles is going to squeal, as were several several others that were present. The opr. went over to the Court room this a.m. with Hope's Son at his request, but did
Completed

not stay any length of time, & on coming back to the Hotel again he met a man named Frisbie one of the Brotherhood from Aurora, he is a very bitter man & says if this man Kelly ever lives to finish his testimony he will be surprised & says he dont think he shall; he says he is going to see some of the boys on the West side tonight, & he also said that he talked to Smith this afternoon & that he (Smith) is not going to give them the worst of it, saying "he will be with us when the time comes;" he also said they were going to show Kelly up before the Court as a man that was no good & one that was a seducer, & that he would not live to give them the worst of it. Ed. Quinnlin came in this Evening from Rochelle & the opr. had a long talk with him while going up to the New Haven Restaurant, he said "the boys have got themselves into a bad fix & I believe they will be convicted." The opr asked him what made him think so, & he said "I would
Completed

not put anything past this man Bowls & I think Bourisen has been led into it with them, I will wait & hear the testimony tomorrow when the Brotherhood can go to hell. I wont have anything to do with an organization that will tolerate any such things to be done. I never did believe in this strike"; he went on and said, if some one dont watch Frisbie, he will kill some one in the Court room as he is a very desperate man, & if he can get any one to go with him he will do anything. Quinnlin also said that he was out to see some of the Santa Fee men & that they are wild for the blood of Kelly, Smith and  M. Givery?  & if they are not careful, something will happen in the Court room. Hope & Murphy have been out much of the time this Evening going North on Clark St. They returned about 11 o'clock & Hope went out again taking his wife with him, he came back to Murphys' room & read a message about some of the Engineers going back
Completed

to work at Kansas City and Omaha, he says that is all right but we will make any of them fellows that go back on the 2 wish they were never born. They are relying on Smiths brother to keep him from giving much bad testimony. Fowler has not come as was expected, but he will be here tonight or tomorrow. Hope has been in constant communication with both he & Thomas, but more especially with Fowler. Murphy has had very little to say since his arrest; they dont any of them appear to know the man Wilson who is under arrest. Murphy & Hope sent out an immense quantity of mail today. Hope goes armed, having a self acting Smith & Weston revolver of 38 Caliber, he has just commenced to carry this and says he intends to carry it from now on, but for what purpose he did not say. The opr. saw opr. J.O. at the Hotel several times today. The day clerk at the Hotel has dissapeared, & no one seems to know what has
Completed

become of him; the opr saw him talking to Hope late yesterday afternoon; the night clerk Hubbard says he came in last eve and said he had to go home as some of his folks were ill, but they dont seem to believe it, he left early this morning. There is a general feeling among most of the men stopping here, that the men now on trial will have a hard time to get clear, but are very guarded what they say in regard to the reason why they think so. The opr tried to get one of the Circulars today that Hope has been sending out, but so far he has been unsuccessful, but will perhaps get one tomorrow. Respectfully Yours Pinkerton Nat. Det. Agency By W. A. Pinkerton Genl. Supt. W Div.  ?
